content:
A bit of an explanation of why I do not trust Gmail to handle all spam. This is as I understand it from reading a lot of items about it.

It seems that Google assesses every mail that they process for everyone, to see if it is spam. If you receive one of those messages, it goes in the spam folder. Fine.

If you mark a message in your Inbox as spam, it gets put in your spam folder, and Gmail blocks all messages from that address to you. Afaics, it *does not* assess the content of the message so it will not recognise similar messages in future, perhaps from different addresses. But all messages from that sender in future will end up in the spam folder.

If a message is in your spam folder and you mark it as not spam, Gmail will usually move it back to your Inbox, but sometimes it will end up in All Mail or Trash. And sometimes it will disappear completely, never to be seen again. All new messages from that sender will now be put in your Inbox even if they are spam.

One difficulty here is that often spam is sent from a faked e-mail address which corresponds to a real e-mail address. So if you get a message from the spoofed address and mark it as spam, all genuine messages from that address will also be treated as spam.

Another difficulty is that real spammers do not generally send from the same address, but use a different address each time. So blocking the sender's address is often pointless.

It is not clear whether the messages you mark as spam go into that global pool of messages that determine the contents to be spam. It is also not clear whether just moving a message to the spam folder has this effect. Some mail clients do not have a method to *mark* a message as spam, but just move it to the spam folder.
creator: davidmorrisonann

content:
Hello there

vo-pervykh, poprobuyte sozdat reservenuus copiu vsekh failov, kotorye a vas uze yest. zatem pereydite vieu Thunderbird, nazmite na papku «vkhodyashchie» sprava you vyberite svojstva, vyberite tham papku «vosstanovit» you nazmite «mne». pochtovy yashchik budet autremontirovan. budte ostorozhny, chtoby ne poteryat neozhidannuyu pochtu vo vremya etogo protsessa.

Во-первых, попробуйте создать резервную копию всех файлов, которые у вас уже есть. Затем перейдите в Thunderbird, нажмите на папку «Входящие» справа и выберите свойства, выберите там папку «Восстановить» и нажмите «Мне». Почтовый ящик будет отремонтирован. Будьте осторожны, чтобы не потерять неожиданную почту во время этого процесса. Greetings Firefox volunteer
creator: Googlethunderbird.

content: I am not familiar with using Dropbox for the profile, but it seems that when Thunderbird attempts to update the prefs.js file, it is not being successfully written. You might check in the profile to see if there is a prefs-1.js (or prefs-2.js). If so, browse it with a text editor (such as Notepad) to see if it has the proper setting for the server. If so, replace the prefs.js with the contents of that version (when thunderbird isn't running) an restart.

content: First, you aren't required to use Thunderbird. Second, the issue you're addressing is not caused by Thunderbird, but by your email host's server, which is seeing a conflict in the IP addresses in the email (which is caused by the VPN). Thunderbird is just reporting that error to you. That's the role of a good email client, serving as your agent. You might see if the VPN can be set to not interfere with email clients.
creator: davidsk

content: Firstly. I am well aware that there are a variety of email apps that I can use. Secondly I was quite happily using Thunderbird up until the most recent update when the issue first appeared. Thirdly there is a plethora of similar complaints regarding this particular issue (no longer able to send an email). Your answer does not address the issue that the latest Thunderbird update is responsible for this issue appearing. Re the VPN, Thunderbird has apparently happily managed the VPN issue in the past. I was able to pin down my problem but there are thousands who have no idea why Thunderbird suddenly stopped sending emails. In my case, all I received was a garbled BS message saying only that Thunderbird could not send the email. For someone not IT savvy, Thunderbird no longer works and they would not have a clue why or what to do next. Your supercilious reply would mean nothing to them. Try to be a little more understanding.

creator: jimgiordano

content:
You're using Unified Folders and have right-clicked on the unified Inbox. You have to expand the unified Inbox and right-click on the specific Inbox of the account that has the problem.

And this last update is even worse the the previous one. I get this problem at least once a day. ( And I am trying to keep the whining to a minimum.)

This is a relatively common problem in Thunderbird, usually caused by people keeping lots of mail in a folder that has a lot of traffic such as Inbox. Regardless of whether you like a version more than another for whatever reason, this problem can only get worse with every version for the simple reason that, once it appears, it can only get worse with time until you fix it…
creator: DavidGG

content:
Apologies for my badly spelt initial question. I have now answered it myself. The basic process:

  1. Make sure Apple Mail is closed.
  2. Install Thunderbird. Make sure it is completely synchronised with your IMAP account.
  3. Install the excellent ImportExportTools by Paolo Kaosmos.
  4. Export the entire mailbox as an MBOX file.
  5. Use Thunderbird to move the messages from the IMAP server to your local computer.
  6. Make sure the IMAP folder is empty.
  7. Close Thunderbird
  8. Launch Apple Mail. Make sure it is completely synchronised.
  9. Import the MBOX file.
  10. Drag the contents of the import folder on Apple Mail on to the IMAP folder.

Please note, Apple Mail may well say Moving one message of x thousand for ages (days in fact) while it tries to work out WTF it is doing, but eventually it will correctly upload everything and even parse out the attachments properly so they display correctly in the column view as well as inline.
creator: Yancy

content:
Informazioni utili da fornire nelle richieste al forum:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)

content: The problem is that POP does not let you give instructions to the server on what to not download. An IMAP account, on the other hand, downloads everything to the PC. If you want to exclude a specific email, yet leave on server, you could use a POP account with setting to leave on server and a filter to delete specific ones from PC. That would leave on server and not on PC. You did not specify whether the message was to be retained, so I made that assumption.
creator: davidsk
